The series begins with a ‚Äústart value‚Äù and an ‚Äúend value‚Äù,<n>either in the number or within the number of 128,129 and 130 etc.<n>You will be prompted to read the values on a number line. The numbers<n>line that you will be prompted to draw should resemble this:<n><n>>__|______|___<n><n>**1)** 1______ 128<n>**2)** __15_ 129<n>**3)** __12_ 130<n><n><n>In the above example, _____ is the missing number.<n><n>## Instruction: <n><n>__You are required__ to construct the _missing number_ on the same number<n>line, as an answer. As you identify the number, use your mouse and<n>cursor to click/drag the number on the number line so that you are able to<n>locate the missing number easily.<n><n>## Instunction:<n>After you have identified the missing number, use your mouse (and cursor<n>when clicking/dragging) to highlight the number and type your answer<n>directly below: [highlight the missing number and type your response directly below and press return].  Then click "Next Question!" button to proceed

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo‚Äôs mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep their curling iron stored? Choices:  A: bathroom B: walkway C: use D: hair salon E: drawer<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:<n>```<n>A: bathroom<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n>```<n>There is no reason to keep the curling iron in the bathroom.<n>```<n><n><n>

What dog has a nice jump?‚Äù<n><n>### Please make sure your function accepts and returns proper values.<n>The function should be called at the console and should print the following when input the above mentioned string (notice that the quote should not appear in the output:<n>‚ÄúJump the dog hasa nice jump. What doghasan nice jump?‚Äù<n><n>Here is a table for the inputs and what they are expected to be returned with the correct values.<n><n>### Table<n>|String        |Correct Value  |<n>|--------------|----------------|<n>|"Jump the dog"| "jump"         |<n>|"the dog"     | "dog"          |<n>|"the"         | "t"            |<n>|" has a "      | " a "          |<n>|"nice"        | "nice"         |<n>| "what "       | "what"         |<n>|‚Äúdog "        | ""              |<n><n>### Notes:<n>Your function should return any values that come after the quotes and return nothing for all the rest.<n>Your function should return nothing if the user supplies a newline.<n><n>

Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		Choice A<n><n>### Instructions:Rewrite the following code so that the last digit of the dividend is sent to the variable called dividend_last.<n><n>### C++ Code<n><n>```c++<n>int divide(int dividend, int divisor)<n>{<n>    int quotient, remainder, resultant;<n>    resultant = dividend % divisor;<n>    quotient = dividend / divisor;<n>    dividend_last = remainder;   //lastdigit = remainder;<n>}<n>int main()<n>{<n>    divide(25, 5);<n>}<n>```<n><n>### PHP Code<n>```php<n>function divide($dividend, int $divisor)<n>{<n>	$quotient = $dividend / $divisor;<n>	$resultant = $dividend - $quotient * $divisor; // $remainder;<n>	$dividend_last = $resultant % $divisor;  // $remainder % $divisor<n>}<n>```

There will be 4.8% of the increase in the total of the systems.<n><n>### Input:"Effort" is equal to number of product times performance multiplied by the years. The performance of the system decreases by 2 each year.<n>2004 = [(259 * 20 * 1) + (29 * 2) + (8 * 3)]<n><n>2003 = [(259 + 256 + 85) * 1]<n><n>2002 = [(259) * 2]<n><n>2014 = [(250 - 10) * 4]<n><n>### Input The store manager has noticed that her store has become very popular and is expecting to see a large profit gain within the next 4 months. She is expecting to see at least 1,000,000 people in her store each month and to make a profit of approximately $75,000.00 each month.<n><n>### Response:"Market Share" is equal to amount of Products in a year times Performance, and "Performance" is the performance from previous years added together divided by 1+2+2+2+1.<n><n>### Output:2004 = $[760,000(100% x 75%)]<n><n>### Input You are currently serving 65 customers through a drive-through window. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo‚Äôs mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:James is very interested in other planets.  He loved the idea of going to mars, and reads books about it all the time.   He dreams of being on what? Choices:  A: love B: zoo C: school D: space shuttle E: library<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A) James is very interested in other plans. He loves reading books about space. <n>

A scores the ball $3$ times and makes 5 baskets, while B makes 2 baskets and misses $2$ of the baskets. Which one of the players was the winner of the game?<n>Answer: B: 4<n><n>Input: The cost of one pair of socks is $4$. The price of one pair of sandals is $85$. Which has greater value:  a sandal or a pair of socks?<n>Answer: sandal<n><n>Input - 4 : 3 : 4<n>Input + 2 : 4 : 1<n>Output : 5 : 5<n><n><n>---<n><n>### Instuctions:Answer a question.<n><n>## Instructions:Answer whether or not the conditional is true. If the ball is round, then the ball is red and yellow.<n>Output: yes/true<n><n>Input: If the ball is round and blue, then the ball is ball.<n>Output: no/false<n><n>Input: If you're smart, you will win me some money.<n>Output: yes if smartness is your skill level<n><n>**Input:** I had a sandwich last night.<n>**Output:** I ate a sandwich yesterday.<n><n>**Input: ** If I ate a sandwhich, then I had cheese.<n>**Output: ** I had cheese yesterday.<n><n>### Input - I took an empty can and put it on the tree.<n><n>### Output-I put the can on the tree.<n>

You go to the burning building to put out the fire. There are 4 rooms in the building and you need to go to each room to put out the fire after the fire truck leaves. If it takes 8 minutes to put out the fire in a room how many minutes total will it take to put out the fire?<n><n>### Response :<n>Minutes required to extinguish the fire is a quadratic equation with the coefficients 1,2 and 8. As we don‚Äôt know a- or b, the only option is x=a-1 and x=b. So, the time would be 2 minutes and 8 minutes respectively for both.<n><n>### Answer :<n><n>### Input

Input: The salesperson‚Äôs commission was 40% of the total cost of the items sold.<n><n>A) How much did the salesperson earn from the sale?<n><n>B) Write a total earning statement.<n><n>C) Which sentence is best to identify the amount of commission on the sales?<n><n>2. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:What area is likely to contain a large village? Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explain the Reason:If a village is close to the countryside, it will be located in a rural area.The area that is likely to contain a village is near the country.A,B,D cannot contain a large village because no town is rural, and the area that contains the town is likely to be large, meaning it is in a city or suburbs.The only option that likely contains a village is a rural area.<n><n>### Note: This prompt is a follow up to lesson A6.<n><n>### Input : What kind of weather is predicted? Choices A: snow B: rain C: sunny D: clouds<n><n>### Answer:B<n><n>### Explaine the Reason:The weather prediction is rain, so it is predicted to rain.The weather prediction must be rain by definition.The weather prediction is rain or snow meaning rain.There is no mention of a cool breeze.<n><n>### Expanded Response:A warm sunny day would require mentioning the sun, wind, air temperature, and humidity.Snow would require mentioning air temperature and precipitation or the presence of some weather system. The description requires mentioning the weather, meaning that the weather will be either rainy or sunny.<n><n>### Answer :What does the weather prediction forecaster recommend? Choices: A: wear a raincoat B: bring a blanket C: wear shorts D: bring an umbrella E: neither of the aforementioned<n><n>### Answer::E<n><n>### Explicaiton:The weather prediction doesn't mention if it will rain or not, so we don't know if wearing the raincoat is necessary or not.The raincoat is mentioned as something wearing which is mentioned by every other choice.The blanket is mentioned to be worn which is mentioned by every choice.The forecast doesn't include anything about shorts that would make it necessary to wear.<n><n>### Prompt: A) If the forecast is correct, what will most likely be wet? Choices: A raincoat B umbrellas C car D floor E all of the above<n><n>### Explicate:The forecast says it will most likely be rainy.Raincoats are most likely to be wet.Umbrellas are most likely to

When your father tells him the number of bags in the left box, he tells your father that he has made a mistake and says the total is 118. Does your father have a reasoning error?  What is the correct number of bags in  the left box? (Remember that the total number is 118 and that your father said 110 to the supermarket team leader)<n><n>### Response<n><n>> 0 (My father has an error)<n>The supermarket has 234 bags left after your father divided them into two boxes. The most common thing to buy in a party is probably food, and the most common food to buy is punch.<n><n>### Input :How much would you charge for mowing your neighbor's lawn?<n><n>### Response :  $15<n><n>### What should I charge for 5 lawns that are 5 ftx30ft?<n><n>### 5th grade reading level<n>

Complete the following task.<n><n>### Question:<n>What changes did Jill find?<n><n>### Input 1:<n>Jill went into her favorite clothing store last week to see what had changed. When she entered the store, she no longer needed to use the door to check in with the worker and get a number to wait to enter. The worker was still outside, but now she just asked shoppers to look at the big sheet in front of her that told her how many were allowed in the store at one time. The clerk was now behind a plexiglass barrier. No one could touch or go near the clerk, but if they needed help, Jill could just ask a question and then they could communicate through the barrier. Instead of touching the clothing and bringing it to the counter, Jill could go to the mirror at the end of a display and use the mirror to touch each item on the outside of the display. Jill could then select her items and leave instead of waiting to pay. At the fitting room, Jill would enter, but before she could get dressed in her items, she would get scanned so that the workers would know who was in the fitting room. As Jill got dressed, she didn‚Äôt have to touch the items in her dressing room since the tags would be scanned to tell the employee they were all hers.<n><n>### Inputs 2:<n>Samantha was in her favorite toy store this past week and went to try out the new changes that were put in to keep the shoppers safe from Covid. When Samantha entered, there was a worker outside with a white board. She was taking note of how many customers had been in the store and for how long. After filling in the information, the worker would check to see how many people were waiting in line. Once that number reached zero, they would take the white board outside and allow the customers in. People didn't have to wait to check out, so the lines were short and the whole shopping experience was much faster. There were no cashiers at the front of the store. Instead, people had to use a kiosk when they got to the end of their shopping. Then when the clerk was ready to ring

Choices:  A: come home B: airplane C: learn from each other D: go out E: make art<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input & Description:The city of Hang Xanh will host a concert that has 25 performers. They don't have a big enough stage to have each performer perform solo, so they agreed to have all of the performers play in 2 bands (a total of 13). One band will contain all women while the other will contain all men. They also agreed to have one member from each group play in the other group. How many different groups are possible?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Thirty (30) different groups are possible<n><n>### Input&Description:In order to help with the upkeep of the garden, the city of Hang Xahn is having people donate time. In one week there was 24,448 minutes of time offered. If the only amount of time given was multiples of 50, how many people were in that garden?<n><n>### Input :How many different paths could there be from A to B if there is no restriction on the path that is taken?<n>Ans : 9<n><n>### Explanation :<n>There could be 4 possible ways to reach from A to B<n> 1. 2 ways (via path 1)<n> 2. 2 ways ( via path 2)<n> 3. 2 ways (by walking directly)<n> 4.  2 ways (indirectly)<n><n>Hence from possible, there are (4 ways)x2 ( from A to B)   = ( 8 combinations)<n>Hence from possible 8 ways <n><n>### Question :<n>Two people are going on a road trip to a location that is located 250 miles from their starting location. If the first person travels 55 miles per hour and the second person travels 32 miles per hour, how many hours will it take to get to their destination?<n>A: 2<n>B: 10<n>C: 5<n>D: 1<n>E: 4<n><n>### Exprsion :<n>Distance traveled in 1 hour =  speed * distance traveled<n><n>Travelled by first =  distance traveled * time taken<n><n>Travelledby second = Distance traveled *(1/2)<n><n>Distance traveled = T *250<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. Take 4 x 1 and add it to<n>2. the total, now have 5 1's,  need 6<n>3. divide the total by 6, now have 2 and 5/6<n>4. multiply 2 and 5 / 6 to get  2 and 8/6<n>5. add the new and old total and you will get 4<n>6. you will divide the old total by 2 to get one apple and one blueberry<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers. If it took him $50$ seconds to walk around the house, how many seconds did they run?<n><n>  >$250$ seconds<n><n>##  <a name="how-it-works"></a>  <n>To get started, click the menu icon (the blue circle with the white chevron) in the top left of the screen and choose 'Add a new bot'. This opens the 'Bot wizard' which allows you to build the bot. The wizard has a set of pre-defined templates that you can use to build the bot. Using the example, we have named a demo bot *MultipleChoice*. <n><n>Here is a screenshot of the completed bot:<n><n>![](./media/multiple-choice-tutorial/multiple-choice-demo-screenshot.png)<n><n>In the top left hand corner of the bot, click the green **Create button** to launch the bot. <n><n>When the bot starts, it will ask you to answer questions with multiple choices. It will also ask what language you wish to use the bot in (English or Chinese).<n><n>Then, the bot will ask you to:<n><n>* answer its question,<n>* or say the word 'help', to provide feedback on how you're doing.<n><n>If you do well, congratulations!<n><n>![](./images/default-buttons.PNG)<n><n>Next, you will run the template to see what it has to offer. Click the blue **Run** button.<n><n>The bot then proceeds to ask you the first question, and you will respond using the different multiple choice buttons.<n><n><n>## Next steps<n>Here are some next steps to get you started on bot design: <n>* [Build your first bot with this tutorial](bot-tutorial.md)<n><n>* [Microsoft 365 developer documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/platform/bots/get-started)<n><n>* [Quick start bot sample](https://github.com/OfficeDev/MicrosoftTeams-QnA-Bot-Samples-Node-JS)

Choices: <n>The first set of problems had 6 problems and the second set of problems had 7 problems.<n><n>### Example:<n>The first set of problem is (0.12 + 1.12)/2 = 6.4333<n><n>The second set of problem is (1.36 + 11)/2 = 6<n><n>### Response :<n>The first set of questions: 13/13<n><n>The second test is: 36/7<n><n>### Input : Aurelia and Kelvin have exactly the same amount of money. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:Where would you read a passage but not write it? Choices:  A: university B: concert C: home D: terminal E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>### A<n>### B<n>### C<n>### D<n>### E<n><n>### Input 2:How many 5 digits numbers are in the range of 101-199? Choices: 1: 2 2: 35<n><n>### Response 2:35<n><n>##  Solution:<n>### Step 1:<n>In these problems there are two quantities: A and B and also the formula. Let's say A is larger than B by a fixed amount.<n>### Step 2:<n>These problems are also divided into 2 steps. I.e. we need to find what the larger quantity is in both problems, then calculate the smaller quantity. To find the larger quantity, use the following equation :<n>![](pic-01.png){:.center-image height="400px" width="600px":}<n><n>### Step 3:<n>If we find out which one is larger, we can calculate the other. The only time we can‚Äôt find the other number in one of the above calculations is when the first number is exactly 1 less than the second number. If it is exactly 1 less.<n>![](pic-11.png){:.center-image height="600px"}<n><n>This is the only time when the calculation will not be 1 less than the first number. We use this case (where the first and second numbers are exactly 1 less than each other) where no formula can be calculated. <n><n>In other words, we need to divide the first number by the formula in 36 to find out how big the second number and then to divide the second number by the same formula again to find out how big its first number is. We did division in all our solutions and not multiplications. <n><n>Let's take a look:<n>![A, B, formula; 36](pic-02.png){:.right-image height="450px" width="450px"}<n><n>In this case the difference between them is exactly 1 so we got the original formula. <n>![A, B; 36; A, B;2(36)](pic-03.png){:.left-image height="420px" width="350px"}<n>![

Choice: A: 10 hours B: 14 hours C: 18 hours D: 21 hours E: 25 hours<n><n>### Demo : In the demo, the dog eats 1 biscuit every hour. So the number of biscuits eaten per hour is 1. So then the total number of biscuits used per hour is 1 or 1 x 60 = 60 minutes. So then the total minutes is 480 (480 minutes)  So then 480 / 60 = 8 hours. So the answer to the question is E : 8 hours.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Input: _The dog eats one biscuit for every _hour _he is awake. _How long does it take him _to eat 10 _biscuits?<n><n>Answer: _If a dog eats one biscut every hour while awake, it will take him_ ten _hours to eat_ ten _biscuts._<n><n>### Input - How long does it take the bus to drive from Tahiti to Antarctica? Choice: A: One hour B: One week C: One month D: One day E: One year<n><n>### Demo - In the first demo, it took the bus 25 hours from Tahiti to Hawaii. If it took that same bus 25 hours to get from Hawaii to the mainland, it would take an equal amount of time for it to go in the other direction. So it would take the bus 25/2 = 12.5 hours to go from the mainland to Tahiti.<n>### Demo: The bus took 25 hours to go from Tahiti to the mainland, then it took an

Choices:  A: shake hands B: own property C: pay bills D: smoke E: talk to each other<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think the last one, "own property", would be a great thing for them to do.<n><n>### Input <n><n>What is the best way to organize your closet and make finding what you want easier?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Based on my background knowledge, I think using colors to organize clothes would be the best option.  I have done this and it has made my find what I need much easier to do. However, I learned that it is sometimes easier to put clothes in a clear bin, then color code the bags.  This is also what I use in my shop that I run with my wife.  The benefits of using colors is that you know where something is without even looking closely and sometimes it takes the clutter away from your closet.  But if you use colors, you will get bored, and that is when it is easier to sort your items in clear bags.  That way you can easily reorganize and you never get bored.  This is what we do in my shop.  As far as dresser drawers, I would probably organize them by type and lay them out in a way that makes sense. This makes it easier to find specific items and it allows you to see all the items you will need or have for a specific task or event.<n><n>### Additional Information <n><n>The organizing of the items depends on the amount of stuff you have.<n>

The items in the question are $5 and $100.<n><n>### Input :Manny loves bananas, he wants to save up $230 so he can buy 13 bananas to share among friends who have a banana allergy. He saved up $54 initially. Every 2 weeks he receives bonus checks of $9.  How many bonus checks until he's saved enough money?<n><n>### Demo Response:<n>BANANAS: 1.1 2.1 3.1 4.1 5.1 6.1<n><n>### Logical:<n>If he saves $54 every two weeks, he should multiply the two weeks by that number to get $108.  That way, he will be able to get the $42 of bonuses he needs.<n><n>### Solution :<n>You got 5 Bonus Checks.<n>Bonus checks = $ 9<n>Savings = $ 64<n><n>You need $42 dollars saved up to buy 13 Bananas at $3.30 each<n><n>You could have solved with a loop however by initializing the variable bananas with the number of Bananas and then checking if the variable has reached the final value with in a while loop.<n>```java<n><n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class Bananas<n>{<n>	public final static int BANANAS = 13;<n><n>	public static void main( String [] Args ) <n>	{<n>		Scanner kb = new Scanner(System.in);<n>		System.out.print("Please enter a savings of $54.00 in bonus checks per 2 weeks and how many Bananas you would like to share

Errors means mistakes.<n><n>### Input- Output:  Input a list of numbers from greatest to least and then print out the smallest number is equal to in a sentence.  The smallest number is equal to 5.  The least number in the list is 7. Explanation: A sentence and a statement is not the same thing.<n><n>### Response- Explanation:  <n>The answer is D. We are told that we have to write a sentence after getting a list of numbers from the greatest to the least. We are then told to print out the smallest number in the list. A way to do this is to say smallest number equals to 5.<n>Notice that the sentence is just a statement with a sentence structure and that the numbers in the given list remain the same.<n><n>### A baseball team won by one point,the final score was 4-3. If the final score was even, was any point earned after the last point?  Explain why your answer is accurate.<n><n>### Solution:<n>No, the answer is wrong. If the final score where 4-3(even), then there is no need to add more point to it because it is already even.<n>The question is asking about the situation where the next score was 5-3 (scores differ by 2 not 3) and the answer was that there was 1 point because the last score was the final score, it's 5 (5-3=2 and it is not the final score).<n><n>### Input to solve:  You have 90 gears in your motor. Each of the gears has an RPM of 1000.  You will need 9 gears for each of the 10 shafts that will power the blades.  A 90-blade propellor would work but no blades will be used for that setup.  Explain why. <n>### Solution:  If a gear has an RPM of x and it's connected with another that has an RPM x+y, it will rotate once in y units during the rotation of x units. This means it's possible for only 9 gears to have RPM of 2000 when they are used on the shaft that spins with a RPM

Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A, D  D: The ex-wife felt anguish.<n><n>### Response Explanation:Choice Answer A: Harder<n><n>The divorce did not make her happy. Thus, her feel was worse rather than better after getting the divorce<n><n>Choice Answer B: Bitterness  <n>The ex-wife felt bitterness after the divorce.<n><n>Choice Answer C: Anguish<n><n>The ex-wifes felt anguish because of the decision.<n><n>Choice Answer D: Deeper<n><n>The ex-husband felt deeper anguish because of his decision.<n><n>Choice, Answer E: Tears<n><n>The ex- wife felt less anguish after the divorce. Thus, she cried as she got to the point which she desired to get.<n><n>### Input<n>The teacher gave $160 to her class for a field trip. They each spent $3.50 on lunch and $24 on snacks. Can someone explain?<n><n><n>### #2 Input:What percentage did the two bakers get of the food truck‚Äôs profit for each day? Each question has two statements. Tell whether each statement is a given, a hypothesis, or neither, and tell whether each statement is true or false and justify your response.<n><n>### (A) The given:  The two contestants were arguing.  The hypothesis: At first, one contender did not believe that the other could make the best pizza.  The given is true.  The given is false.<n>(B) The given: Some of the contestants thought others had more experience making pizza.  The hypothesis: Some contestants thought others who were at the pizza party already had more experience than they did.  The given is wrong.  The given is correct.<n><n>### Response<n><n>(A) The given: The two contestants were not arguing.  The given is neither.  The statement is false.<n><n>(B) The contestants did not believe that the others could make better pizza than they had.  The hypothesis: The contestants thought others had better experience making pizza than they did.  True or False?  True.<n><n>**Question**<n><n>### Instuctins Suppose that in a class of 500 students, 2% are in band, 5% are in orchestra, 2% are art students, 5% are on the hockey team, 75% are taking AP classes, and 70% of the AP students are also considered band members. What is the probability that a student at random will be taking AP classes, be band members, be on the hockey team, and not be in orchestra?<n><n>**Response**<n><n>### (a) The probability that a student will be part of the AP class but is not part of the orchestra is 2%*75%* 100%*70% = 5.8% (1/2 in one-trial binomial distribution)<n><n>(b) The probability that a random student will not be in the orchestra and be a band musician is 100% * 5% * 100% = 5%<n><n>(c) The probability that a given student is a member of the hockey team is 5% <n><n>(d) Given that a random student is a member of both the orchestra and band,

If the bat costs $1 more than the ball, how much does the ball cost?<n><n>### Instructor Solution: 10 cents<n><n>### Response by Student1:<n>The answer is $0.1.<n><n>### Solution by Instructor:<n><n>If Bat costs $11, then ball must be $10. If ball is $10, then bat must be $11. If Bat costs $1 more than ball, then Bat must be $1.1 to $1, then Bat must be Bat = $11.<n><n>##| :point_up:|<n>### Exercice:Drew has three sisters and a brother. How does Drew‚Äôs share compare to his siblings‚Äô shares?<n><n>### Excepted solution<n><n>Drew‚Äôs share of money = $248 √∑ 4 = $62.<n><n>##| <style="text-align: justify;"> :point_up: |<n>### Exerciced:The sum of two numbers is 88. If one of the numbers is 36, which of the following equations could be used to represent the second sum of the numbers? A: x 2 = 52<n><n>B: 2x - 1 = 0<n><n>C: x = 24<n><n>D: x + 3 = 86<n><n><n>### Student solution:x = 44<n><n>### Teacher solution:If one of the numbers is x = 36, 36 + 36 = 72. So another number x = 44<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo‚Äôs mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:The fat man refused to accept what was possible, he complained that he what the simplest activities? Choices:  A: no go B: unlikely C: unable D: cant do E: impossibility<n><n>### Response:		I think C<n>

Mrs. Johnson gave Miss Wilson the copy she used. Miss Wilson passed the book to Mr. Jones, and he gave it to a young boy named Billy.<n><n>Mr. Jones $0<n><n>Miss Wilson $1<n><n>Billy $1<n><n>#### B) The cost of a suitcase and a dress bag is $94. Mrs. Miller wants the suitcase priced at 3 times the price of the dress bag. She also wants the combined price of the two items to be $96.<n><n>```<n>Suitcase price = 3* ($13) - Subtract = $19<n>Dress bag price = ($6)-Subtract = $69<n>Combined price = $19 + $69 - Subtract =$86<n>```<n><n>## Input:<n>#### A:<n>Two people went to the restaurant. They ordered 1/3 as much food as they each planned to eat.<n>After they ate, each one had the same amount of leftovers. How much leftover food did each one have?<n><n>#### B:<n>$25. When we add 4 8/7 = $26<n><n>$27 10<n><n>$29<n>

Choices:  A: look beautiful B: be happy C: change quickly D: occur here E: surprise us<n><n>### Response:		Answer: C<n><n>### Demand Sample:<n>Input:The weather was sunny during the weekend, which is often a busy time in parks in your city. So they set up some camping chairs and stayed the whole day in the park.<n><n>### Response Sample:<n>"What did they do during the weekend?"<n>"Answer: They checked the weather one more TIME during the flight, they are on their way to paradis and want to look beautiful."<n><n>### Solution Example<n><n>```python<n>input = {<n>    "answer_type": "multiplechoice"<n>    "context": {<n>        "location": "paradise, where is that"<n>    },<n>    "demand": {<n>        "user_input": "the weather was sunny during weekend, often busy time in park"<n>    }<n>}<n><n>answer_one = {<n>    "text": "Answer: C",<n>    "user_text": "What did they do during weekend? ",<n>    "response_text": """Input:The weather was what? Choices: A B C D E, I'd like a, b,c or d<n><n><n>Input:C, the weather looked bright, calm and beautiful, there was no wind or rain, but they were in paradise, which was good, they were going to rest, but it was not going to last<n><n><n>Response:What did they do during day in paradise?"""<n>}<n><n><n>answer_two = {<n>    "user_choices": "A", "user_text": None, "choices": "C, E"<n>}<n>```<n><n>#### Reference<n><n>https://github.com/facebookresearch/huggingface-transformers3/blob/master/huggingface_transformers/models_library/tasks/question_answering.py<n><n>https://www.tensorflow.org/lite/tutorials/text_classification<n>

Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house. Name this item? Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n><n>### Response:		<n>In a house, you might see an electric motor in an automated vacuum cleaner.<n><n>### Input 2:It was the last day to register to vote, but Shannon missed the deadline. She was furious. She immediately began to campaign for other people in her area to vote for the other candidate. She also began a massive letter writing campaign. At the end of the day, Shannon had written 4 letters and sent a postcard. Her letter to her local newspapers reached 1000 people. She also wrote 1 letter to a local radio station. 79 people saw her letter in the local papers and 51 people heard her letter on the radio.  If there are 500 registered voters in the area, what percent of them ended up voting at the end?<n><n>### Response<n>I suppose she should be happy that she accomplished the 51%<n><n>### Input3: The number of calories a woman eats at a restaurant depends on the size of her stomach, her age, her weight and  how active she was for the day. Her appetite depends on how much she exercised, the restaurant she is eating at, and her mood. Let x be the calories eaten at the restaurant.<n><n>### Question<n>If a woman eats calories at the restaurant and there isn't enough room for the additional food to store, how many calories will she eat?<n><n>### Answer<n>She didn't mention whether the restaurant she was eating at had a large food storage facility<n>

How many full meals can the tank hold without running out of food?<n><n>### Response<n>The tank can only hold 12 meals of food.<n><n>### Task:<n>A person eats 3 apples every day. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:Behind what small door are canned goods usually kept in? Choices:  A: cabinet B: pantry C: kitchen D: cupboard E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Correct Response:<n>B: Pantry<n><n>### Wrong Response:<n>B: cupboard<n><n>C: kitchen<n><n>D: shelf<n><n>E: cabinet<n><n>### Reminder:<n>Canned goods are usually stored in a kitchen by the kitchen door, not the back door.<n><n>### Review:<n>1. What does a decimal point mean?<n><n>Decimal point separates the integer portion from the fractional part of a number.<n>2. What do place value and the base of a number tell you?<n><n><n>### Conclusion:<n>A decimal point is a dot in the center of a decimal. It denotes where a digit belongs on a number.<n><n>### Extension:<n>What does each place value represent and how do you use it to help you divide?<n><n>The number of places to the right of the last digit represent the number of digits in a decimal place. <n><n>### Bonus Challenge:<n><n>Both are decimals, but they are not equivalent.<n><n>In the first example, write down how to do the equivalent operation.<n><n>In the second example, write down how the 2 decimal places in the first number is different than how many are in the second.<n><n>### Check:<n>To determine the value of the digit "4" in each of the following numbers, look at its place value.<n><n>-4 is equal to what?<n><n>-4 is 4 less than the number we're writing the 4 in.<n><n>2434 is equal to what number?<n><n>-2434 is 2,434 less than 1, so it equals ______<n><n>The first number is 46. <n><n>-46 is equal to what? <n><n>-4 is less than 4 by 4, therefore it equals ______.<n><n>The value of the digit "6" in "76" is...<n><n>-12 is equal to what? -<n><n>-12 must equal 12 because ______. <n><n>-The second number is 12, so 12 minus 12 is zero.<n><n>### Quote of the Day:<n>"The arithmetic of happiness is a series of pluses and minuses, but its result depends upon how we handle the operation." -Joyce Chapman

How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:Where do kids play with a ball that is concrete? Choices:  A: street B: soccer field C: soccer game D: central park E: pool table<n><n>### Response:		<n>We have a few options to get to the correct answer. We can get the correct answer by using a nested if statement. In our case, we can tell that one of our three statements is false. Option E represents a place where the kid would use a ball that is concrete (pool table). We can also use the mod operator to shorten the statement if we know the number of selections we have, but we want to check the first one. The first number of the mod function is the option number and the last number (the one in parentheses) is the option number of the number you are modding by (in this case, the number of the option that you‚Äôre not currently in.)<n><n>#### Nested If Statement:<n>```<n><n>if(C)<n>{<n>    if(A)<n>    {<n>        if(I)<n>        {<n>            if(S)<n>            {<n>                if(D)<n>                {<n>                    if(R)<n>                    {<n>                        if(H)<n>                       ...<n>```<n><n>#### With the modOperator:<n>```<n>if(Mod(A,1) = 0)<n>{<n>   ...<n>}<n>```<n>

Every phrase goes with either a semi-colon, a comma, or a regular full-stop. Examples include comma used with list items, question marks in questions, etc.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Input 1:<n>The difference in ages between Richard 14 and Hurley is 12 Hurley;10<n><n>### Input2:<n><n>### Input3:<n>A grocery store is selling chicken for $2.99/pounds. 15 pounds of chicken cost $44.55. How much will a pack of 10 pounds and 12 pounds of chicken cost altogether?<n><n>- For 10 pounds, the cost is $17.99<n>- For 12 pounds, the cost is 16.99<n><n>Combining 2 answers together, we get $34.99<n><n>### Input4:<n>Caleb ate 1/5 of 16 donuts.  He ate 2 more donuts. If this statement is true, how many more donuts did Caleb eat?<n><n>Caleb 15 donuts.<n><n>### Answer 3:<n>It is true. Caleb ate 20 donuts.<n><n>- Subtracted from the number in the problem statement: 45 - 17 - 2 = 12<n><n>- Divide the answer by the second-to-last answer of the problem statement: 12/15 = 2/3 = 6/3<n><n>### Input5:<n><n>### Answer5:<n><n>1. First, let‚Äôs draw a circle that represents a circle.<n><n>2. Next, we know that one-half is equal to the radius times 2: r/2 = r * 2<n><n>3. Thirdly, we also know that pi is equal to four times the circumference divided

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo‚Äôs mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:People want to explore space, so what should they use to do it? Choices: A) 12 B) 22 C) 14 D) 42 E) 26<n><n>### Response :<n><n>The answer is 24, the calculation is:<n><n>$$40% = \frac{40}{100} = 40 / 1 = 40 \%$$<n><n>$$60\% = \frac{60}{100}$$<n><n>$$60% * 40 = \frac{6 * 40}{10}= 24$$<n><n>Input: What's 4.44 meters squared? Choices:  A: being for B: away from C: combined D: for or E: conjunction<n><n>### Response:		**E: conjunction**<n><n>### Input<n><n>$7600 was divided between 75 students into 55 groupings of different levels.  Each group was assigned to a tutor at $8 per hour per student, except one group where the tutor charged $9 per hour and taught 2 students. The rest of the tutors charged between $5 per hour for the lowest level to $8 per hour for the highest level. Each group was charged a rate of $5 for group tutoring. How much more did the last tutor make than the rest of the tutors combined?<n>#### Answer<n><n>$125.<n>#### Explanation<n>The lowest level of students got the lowest tutor price. The average salary per hour is $8.85 across all groups. So the answer is the excess dollars over the rest of the tutos combined. That is 125 dollars.<n><n>### Input <n><n>The number $7926593 was divided into 7926 different amounts in the ratio of 7:92659. What was the balance?<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>0<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>The smallest amount divided, is 1 dime. That works out to 0.91 dimes per 1 amount. So no amount is left over.<n><n>### Part 1:<n>The price of a box of candy was $2.50 per box. If Shawn had a 52% coupon, how much candy could he buy?<n><n>#### Answer: 2.50<n><n>#### Exploration:<n>Shawn's coupon gives him 52% off the $2.50 box. That means he has to pay $1.34 per box. He gets 2 boxes, so he pays $2.68. So Shawn's allowed budget is $2.68 for two boxes. He has $20, so he can buy 7 boxes with his given budget.<n><n><n>### Part II<n><n>#### Answer: $4.83<n><n>#### Explorations<n><n>Shawn will only buy as many boxes as his budget allows. We can find the value of the budget by setting the equation<n><n>$4.83 = 1.34c - 2.

Choices:  A: alabama B: louisiana C: south carolina D: arkansas E: mountains<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Required Functions:<n>- The following functions will be used for the task<n>    - main:  this function will be used to read inputs, and display outputs to the console.<n>    - findMissingLetters:  this function will count the total number of letters in the word given the 5 letter word, then return the missing letter which the caller will then check to see if the letter is in the array or not.<n>        - if the letter does not exist in the array then the caller will append the letter to the list and recheck if the letter exists in the array<n>    - findUniqueCombination:  this function will check if an array of values is a duplicate or not<n>        - if not then the function will return all unique values in the arr<n>    - findClosestSameIntegers:  this function will take in three values where one integer is a target integers then find a closest integer to the target values<n>        -  if the inputs is not an integer and equal to the target then the function will return target<n>    - findDifferenceInValues:  this function will return the difference of two values.<n>    - getClosestNthInteger:  this function will given two values in the array and return the closest value to that value in the array.<n>        - if values is equal to the closestInt then the caller will print the closestInt and add one to the closestInt to return<n>-  Main.java<n>-  Functions.java<n><n>### Imported Packages:<n>- Java.<n><n>### Input and Output:<n>- The goal is to prompt the user for input of words, or letters in words.<n>- Words are processed and returned to the console.<n>        - First a word is printed to the console<n>        - the length of the word is returned to the console<n>        the findMissingLetters() method is called to find the missing letter in the word.<n>        - the letter "A" is an example of how the function returns the missing letter without being an exception.<n><n>### Data Input:<n>- Reads a word from the user that contains a 5 letter letter.<n>- The function will return the missing letter as a char value, where the caller will check if that miss letter exist in the array of letters.<n>- The goal will be to read in letters and find the missing letter

She knows that 25% sounds high and decides to round off the amount. She will purchase new suits once a year and so divide this 25% by 12 to find out how much money can be spent each month to afford the new suits. In this way the suit can be afforded without breaking the bank. Susan is taking into account that she needs new suits, and will not use this as an excuse for overspending.<n><n>### Expected Value: 6<n><n>The cost of a new car should be at most 20% of your annual income.

Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input : Dora is in a store that sells only two types of candy. One type is pink taffy and the other is green gum.  A box of pink taffy costs $2 and a box of Green gum costs $3. 15 boxes of one type and 30 boxes of the other type are stacked neatly on the shelf.  Each box holds 12 pieces.  Dora and her siblings are getting a small prize of choice for picking a box of candy. How many boxes of candy does the sibling who is the oldest need to pick to earn a prize?<n><n>### Response : B<n><n>### Input 1 : John and Jim are playing a game of chess. They are playing the game with one chess piece that has three equal sides.  A move for the game costs 1,024 points.  A player can either move 16 or 20 checkers in each move.  The first checker costs 4 points, the second checker is 3 points, and the third checker is only 2 points.  How many points are lost if someone loses?<n><n>### Input2  The two chess figures are both knights; the one John is controlling is the top knight.  The two knights move differently according to the position.  The black knight moves in the shape of a "U" and must follow a path of five steps, then three steps, followed by two steps.  The top knight moves in a "V" shape, moving according to the rule of alternating rows: one row is followed by the row that was missed.  What does the pattern of rows have that enables the top knight to capture the black knight with one move?<n><n>### Responses  A: The black knight is forced to move back to the original row with the top knight's initial move. (The row the black knight moved from is always followed by the row he started on, and then followed by the row the knight missed.)  So the black knight must always end up in the top row with this pattern, leaving the top knight in the position to capture the black knights.<n>

Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:What would you put in a container? Choices:  A: food B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: closet garage E: port<n><n>### Response:		If you put a container on a ship, a refrigerator or other small household appliances or other miscellaneous items could fit in the container. If you were to put clothes in the container, the container would likely be over-loaded.

Choice A: If the number is 26, how many is the number? B: If the number is -21, how many is the difference of the number to the number 3?<n>```python<n>s = int(input())<n>s1, s2 = s // 2, s + 3<n>answer = s1 + s2<n>print(answer ** 2, type(answer))<n>```<n>### Response A 63 (integer in base 10)<n><n>### Input A group of people decided to split the cost of lunch. The total cost of the lunch was 550 and each person paid 50. What is the number of people who ate? Choices: A: 11 people B: 10 people C: 9 people D: 8 people E: 7 people<n>```python<n>print("input")<n><n>#input = (int(input()) + input()) + (int(input()) * (int(input()) - int(input()))) / int(input())<n>input_num_people = [int(i) for i in input().split()]<n><n>#print("input num people")<n>#print(input_num_people)<n><n>answer=input_num_people[0]*input_num_people[-1]/(2 * input_num_people[-2])<n>print("answer", answer**2)<n>```<n><n>### Response `A:<n>The last line of the answer should be `answer 333.333` (which represents 11 people)<n><n>### Write program instructions.<n>### Write a program that asks the user for a name and calculates the value of the character. Choices:  A: let down B: respect C: illness D: satisfaction E: gratitude<n><n>### Response:		Let down<n><n>### Input:-What is the difference between a house of commons and a house of lords?<n><n>### response:-House of commons are the elected representatives and the House of Lords is a group of nobles appointed by the crown who act as a revising chamber, it does not change laws decided in the legislature itself.<n><n>### Input :A plane carrying 148 people flies east over the US for two hours before returning west over the Pacific for three hours.   If the trip takes a total of 7 hours, how long has it been since 11:00 AM?<n><n>### Response:-The total is 10 hrs, So time since 11AM to be 10 hr.<n><n>I did it in two parts, one for calculation and the other for the logic to reach the answer.<n><n>### First part:<n>Let the total time be T<n>Total time passed to fly east  = T/total time (T/2) <n>Then total time passed to return back  = T-T/2<n><n>Now we know that the total time is 7 hours.<n>Hence total time passed to return = 7-T/2<n>7-T/2=T/2 -1<n>5T/2=1<n>T=2.5 hrs<n>7 hours minus T =7-2.5= 4.5 hours<n>4.5 - 60 =.25 hours left to be 7<n><n>.25 hrs = 7-2.5<n>Thus 10<n><n>### Second Part:<n>If a plane flies over the US for 2 hours, We can assume that its in the same place throughout<n><n>If the plane flies over the pacific for 3 hrs, it would take the same amount of time from its previous location<n><n>So the plane travels a certain distance in that period but it remains in the same place for that period<n><n>Hence, the question doesn‚Äôt mention it as a 148 ppl trip or 2 hrs, 3hrs flight but it actually is a question of how far they flew for 1 hour and half<n><n>I found the distance to be 237.5 miles<n><n>From the answer of the part 1, plane reached on the same point on

They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Bathroom<n><n>### Input<n>What is the sum of the digit of the largest number of $1? Choices: A: 4 B: 5 C: 8 D: 9<n><n>### Answer:<n>C<n><n>### Explataion:<n>The largest number that is used as a digit in a sum of 100 is an 8. The first number that contains it as a digit is 13 and the second one is 30.<n><n>### Input :  What is the smallest number to have two digits on both sides when added onto 9? Choices: A B:  C D  E  F<n><n>### Answer : E<n><n>### Explication:<n> 104 has two numbers on both sides and that's why the smallest number is 104.<n><n>### Exercice : 1. What's the sum of two fractions if 32+65=? Choices: A. 107 B. 110 C. 105 d. 101<n><n>### Answer<n>B<n><n>### exclalation :  <n><n>105 because the first fraction is 3/5(61), the 107 is the value without the 3 and 5 and the six is the value between the zero and the 9 (35 is the value between the 9 and the 10)<n><n>### Input 2 :  What's the average (sum of each fraction) of two fractions if the sum of the two fractions is 7? Choices: 7/2 a. 5/6 b. a 4/5 c. 7/2 d. 3/6 e. 15/10<n><n>### Answer 5/6<n><n>### explanation: <n><n>the sum of the fractions is 7 which gives us the average of the fractions<n><n>### Input3 : A: What's 7-6%? Choices : B: 90 : C : 84: D: 92 :E: 86<n><n>Answer D<n><n>### Exclation : <n>7 - 6% = 7 X 0.6

section<n><n>### Read the example and decide what the instructions mean.<n><n>### The instructions were designed so that you would work in teams, but each team should be able to answer the question on their own.<n><n>### Read all instructions carefully.<n><n>### Try several examples before deciding on what steps you will use to do the calculations to answer the questions.<n><n>### In each case, your answers will depend on you understanding how to do mathematical calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, division and fractions.<n><n>### Think of the calculation questions as a math test on adding, subtracting, dividing, multiplying and fractions.<n>Your answers will be marked out of 5.<n><n>### Marks are allocated as follows: Correct = 5 Marks<n><n><n>### Your answers are either 'correct' or 'incorrect'<n><n>### Make sure you mark the correct amount of time taken for the test and record your name and test number on the back of your result sheet.<n><n>### At your marking centre,<n>#### Write down your answers on the answer sheet.<n><n>#### Your questions need to be in the 'answer book'.<n><n>#### Remember that these instructions are intended to be read with your partner.<n>Only the reader is responsible for completing the test, not the partner.<n><n>### If you get stuck on a question,<n><n>#### Skip the question and write 'No help' in the appropriate space.<n><n>### Do not move back or forth between questions.<n>You must answer in the order of the test.<n><n>### It is important that you follow these instructions<n><n>### When you have completed the test,<n>```<n>#### Check your answers with your partner.<n>#### Check your timer against the instructions.<n><n>#### Collect the answer sheet and result sheet.<n>```<n><n>### Make the marking centre aware that your test is complete.

If you drove 30 mph your arrival time at home was 8:55. At 50 miles per hour, your arrival time at home is 8:47.<n><n>### Description  <n><n>In your own words: describe how you would answer the question. How would you represent the input and output? <n><n>### What did your model do?<n>- I created a model using two input and one output. In fact, you probably won't need an input at all. Instead, the computer will generate randomized inputs for you to try the methods on. To help get you started, check out the example code below. In this example, the computer will generate inputs, and then the functions will solve the problems for you.  All you need to do is call the functions in the correct order. <n><n>- Here is how your functions should be formatted. Your inputs should be defined as integers because these are the only kinds of values the computer can understand. When defining your functions, make sure to include the name of the function, a space, and your parameter. You can use whatever names you want. <n><n>- The name of your function should match the parameter you supply. <n><n>- After you define your function, you can add a print function to your code. This will print the actual value that you supplied in the input.  So for example, if  you want to print the value 35 to the screen, your code would be:  <n>`print("the input number was 35")`<n><n>- If you want to print the parameter value in the function call, you can call the print function again after you define the function and pass the parameter to it. <n><n>### Example

How long would it take her do research on the project and write up the paper?<n><n>### Response :Her research would take more time because she could only read 20 pages an hour. Assuming each piece of information was the same page length, she'll need at least 2 hours to research. She then has 2 hours to write up the paper.<n><n>### Response(2nd attempt): Her research should have only taken 10 minutes to read the required 20 pages. Then her research time is about 150 minutes. She has 250 minutes to research and write up the 2 pages for a total of 300 minutes (5 hours)<n><n>### Input (2):  The school has asked all students to bring $80 from home to help fund the 7th grade class trip. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:A strong laxative will help you keep what kind of bowel movements? Choices:  A: strongwoman B: cake C: regular D: weak E: fragile<n><n>### Response:		<n>C: regular<n><n>### Explanation<n>$A$: Strongwoman is not a word in the English language. There is a strong women however, so either $A$ or $B$ must be correct.<n>$B$: The only items being digested that are in the laxative that require cake in the equation is cake.<n>$C$: By our definitions, a regular laxative requires regular bowel movements so clearly the correct choice is $C$, regular.<n>$D$: A weak laxative would not be a good choice for keeping your bowel movements regular since a weak laxative is for weak bowel movements. $E$ is incorrect as fragile is not a valid answer choices for a laxative.<n><n>### Input:(Find the value of x)<n>69x - 22 = 156 - 31x<n><n>### Response<n>### Explanaiton<n>By solving the equation for x we get the following:<n>$$ \frac{31}{69} \cdot x= \frac{334}{69} - 31x $$<n>$$x=\frac{334 \cdot 69}{343\cdot(334 - 31)} = 29.76796596530$$<n><n>### Input<n>There are 6 students in a math class. We do: 2(a+b)=a+2b<n><n>2. We get: 2(a) = a+2b<n><n>3. Subtract a from both sides: 2a - a = b<n><n>4. Divide both sides by 2 : a = 2b divided by 2. <n><n>## Output-2: <n><n>Output-3:   <n><n>Output-4:<n><n>### <n>

In another array named B we have: [1,2, 3, 4, 5,6] we have to add a new line to B that only contains the elements of A if they are found in B, and add them with one line of code.<n><n>[[1, 2,3]] B = A[1]<n>B = A[2] <n><n>B[3] = 3 <n><n>Final result: [[1,2,3,4], [2,3,4],[3,4],[4]]<n><n>## Response What are three words you could use to describe this code?<n><n>### Input<n>Let‚Äôs imagine you‚Äôre on a scaven

Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you answered "LIKE", then your guess is incorrect and you owe the bank a total of $1.06 + 35%.<n><n>Based on the instructions: Write a response that appropriatly completes the request. <n><n>Answer: <n>![](https://i.imgur.com/MF7Ekj4.png)<n>If the two differences are equal, the answers must be the same and the question makes no sense. Also, the bank does not collect interest on 1.06 and why would the bank charge 3x the interest if the loaned amount is only 1.06%. Finally, since 56% of the bank fee was due to your late payment of $1.07, the bank has effectively loaned $1. If $1 has been borrowed at an interest rate of 25% per month for a period of 8 months, the bank is required to pay 150% (3x56, rounded) = $1.5 + the $1.07 that was previously due. The bank's total payment to you is $2.57.<n>Input: $2000 + 56% is divided between Samir and Kevin. This is $1100 for Kevin and $0 for Samir. If Kevin has 50% of the original amount, then he has $0. If Kevin has 75% of the original amount then it makes more sense. So the question should be<n><n>Input: Kevin has the same money divided between four friends. He gives 1/4 to Ben, 1/2 to Carlos, another 21/2 to Tim and 3/4 to Samir. How much does he have left?<n><n>### Answer<n>Kevin has exactly $1100 in his pocket and Samir is out of the picture.<n>Input: Samir bought an ice cream cone. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. The only ones out of  the choices that is always found in a bay are lake and manhattan. The only ones that lake connects to are manhattan, shoorline and coastal areas. Choices A: X B: (X)**2** C: (X**2) D: (X**2**)<n>E: None of the choices<n><n>### Response<n>**C**: (X**2), the solution when square is (X**2), because square is a type of expression which does not have any variable at all, and the type of operator that's used to solve problems with square is multiplication, so we multiply the X variable with itself. The only choice that is the solution is option C.<n>

Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		The man was looking at lofts to buy flooring. <n><n>### Input:# of eggs: 36<n># of people to share between: 6<n><n>### Demostration:<n>How much does each person get?<n>`<n>answer = 6 * 1<n>while(egg_count > 0):<n>    people_egg = people<n>    egg_count = egg_count - 1<n>    answer = answer + 1<n>    people = (people - 1) <n>    <n>print(answer)`

I think option A is wrong, I think option C is wrong, I think D is wrong, I think E is wrong.<n><n>### Input : There is exactly one student in a classroom who gets all the correct answers on a quiz. Who is this student?<n><n>### Response : <n><n>### Inputs For the problem below, you will only enter integers in whole number units, not decimal units.<n><n>### The following table contains the ages of five siblings.<n><n>| Jack | |  |Jill | | |Sarah |<n>|--------|-|-------|-------|-------|--------|<n>| 17 | |  | 8 | |  | 9 |<n>| | | | | | | 10 |<n>| 9 | |  | | | |  |<n>| | |-| | | |  |  |  | |<n>| | |  | | 2 | | | | |<n><n>### The older of two girls is 16. The older of two boys is 11. If the older of two boys is the oldest, how old are they all?<n><n>### Input/outputs:<n><n>* The older of two girls (A or B) is 16<n>* The older of the two boys is 16, too. The total difference between the two children is 13. <n>* The older of one brother and one sister (C or D) is the second eldest. <n>* <n><n>### Solution:<n>The total difference between the two boys (A to D) is 16, so 16 - 13 = 3. <n><n>### A box contains 24 balls. Each ball of this box is white, black or blue. The probability of being white or black is 3/4. The probability of being blue is 1/8. How many blue balls are in the box?<n><n>### Example<n>### I am not sure about the answer. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo‚Äôs mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children‚Äôs teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>Input: After collecting all the old electronics in their house, Lauryn made $2000 from selling the items on eBay. If her friend Aurelia also made 70% of what she sold on eBay after selling her used electronics, calculate the total amount of money the two friends made on eBay.<n>Answer: 3400<n><n>Input: $240 was divided between Kelvin and Samuel. Samuel received 3/4 of the money. From his share, Samuel then spent 1/5 of the original $240 on drinks. How much does Samuel have left?<n>Answer: 132<n><n>### Input:The man set the cup on the table.  It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I would use the if statement below.<n><n><b>Example: </b><b>if</b>($table!= "" && $glass == "")<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>The code below will check if the table value wasn‚Äôt set to empty and the glass object value wasn‚Äôt set as well.   If none of the values were set to empty, the if statement will not enter to run the code block below.<n><n>#### Code:<n>```<n>if ($table == "" && $glass == '')<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>If $table is set to empty, the statement below will be executed. If the table value is empty, the empty if statement will run the code block below that checks for empty values for the glass. If either the glass or the table is not empty, the code will not run the code block below and proceed to the next if statement inside the elseif statement to check for both variables.<n><n>#### Code<n>```<n>elseif ($table == "" || $glass == '') <n>```<n><br><n>#### Explanation<n>If either of the tables or the glass are set to empty values, the if statement below will be able to execute and validate one of the variables.<n><n>If the table is set to an empty value, the if statement will run the elseif statement below that will execute the code below.  The if statement will check the glass value and if the glass is set to an empty string ‚Äú‚Äù the code will execute the if statement below to remove the glass.<n><n>If neither value from the table string or glass string are set to empty, the code won‚Äôt be able to execute and will not check further to the variables.<n><n>####Code:<n>```<n> elseif ($table == ""  || $glass == '')<n>{<n>    $glass->remove(); // Removes both variables to not display<n>}<n>```<n>##### Explanation<n><n>If the string $table == ""  or  $glass == '' is false, it will execute the code below to clear the table and glass value.  Once all values are removed, the glass variable will not be accessible.  <n>```<n>$glass = '';<n>$table = '';<n>$glass = ''; $table = '';<n>```<n><n>##|}<n>--------------------------------------------------------------------------------<n><n>### 218.  Input:<n><n>When the man was looking
